sections.text: Use comparative verbs to show how things are similar or different. These verbs are more formal and precise than using 'be similar/different'.
resembles (formal similarity), takes after (family/style), has...in common (shared features), compares to/with (general comparison).
differs from (neutral difference), contrasts with (strong opposition), distinguishes...from (what makes something unique), varies from (changes).

examples.text: This smartphone resembles the previous model.
examples.explanation: Use 'resembles' for formal similarity between things.

examples.text: Her approach differs from traditional methods.
examples.explanation: Use 'differs from' to show how things are different.

examples.text: Tom takes after his father in personality.
examples.explanation: Use 'takes after' for family resemblance or inherited traits.

examples.text: His views contrast with her beliefs.
examples.explanation: Use 'contrasts with' to show strong opposition or difference.

examples.text: Both languages have much in common.
examples.explanation: Use 'have...in common' to talk about shared features.

examples.text: Quality distinguishes this product from others.
examples.explanation: Use 'distinguishes...from' to show what makes something unique.

examples.text: We need to compare the two options.
examples.explanation: Use 'compare' for general comparison (more common than 'make a comparison').

examples.text: Prices vary depending on location.
examples.explanation: Use 'vary' to show things differ or change.

examples.text: The results correspond to our predictions.
examples.explanation: Use 'correspond to' when things match or align.

examples.text: This painting resembles the work of Monet.
examples.explanation: Use 'resembles' for similarity in style or appearance.

title: Comparative Adjectives
subtitle: similar to, different from, identical to

sections.text: Use comparative adjectives with 'be' to describe relationships between things. These create more formal, precise comparisons.
similar to, identical to, comparable to, equivalent to, the same as. Note: 'alike' has no preposition.
different from, distinct from, dissimilar to. Remember: 'different FROM' (not 'different than' in British English).

examples.text: This design is similar to the original.
examples.explanation: Use 'is similar to' for general resemblance.

examples.text: The two contracts are identical.
examples.explanation: Use 'identical' when things are exactly the same.

examples.text: Her style is different from conventional methods.
examples.explanation: Use 'is different from' (not 'different than') in British English.

examples.text: Your conclusion is the same as mine.
examples.explanation: Use 'the same as' when things match exactly.

examples.text: One kilogram is equivalent to 2.2 pounds.
examples.explanation: Use 'equivalent to' for equal value or status.

examples.text: Her accent is distinct from a British one.
examples.explanation: Use 'distinct from' to emphasize clear, noticeable difference.

examples.text: This qualification is equivalent to a master's degree.
examples.explanation: Use 'equivalent to' for equal academic or professional status.

examples.text: The twins are very alike.
examples.explanation: Use 'alike' without a preposition (not 'alike to').

examples.text: This price is comparable to last year's.
examples.explanation: Use 'comparable to' when things can reasonably be compared.

examples.text: These findings are different from earlier studies.
examples.explanation: Use 'different from' to show contrast with previous information.

sections.text: Shows two things changing together in a parallel way. Pattern: the + comparative + clause, the + comparative + clause.
Connects two positive elements of equal importance. Shows something has two qualities or two things happen together.
Neither...nor: two negative elements (I like neither coffee nor tea). Either...or: choice between two options (either today or tomorrow).

examples.text: The more you practice, the better you become.
examples.explanation: Use 'the more...the better' to show parallel improvement.

examples.text: She speaks both French and Spanish.
examples.explanation: Use 'both...and' to connect two equal positive elements.

examples.text: The higher the prices, the lower the demand.
examples.explanation: Use 'the...the' to show inverse relationship between two things.

examples.text: I like neither coffee nor tea.
examples.explanation: Use 'neither...nor' for two negative elements.

examples.text: The earlier you leave, the sooner you'll arrive.
examples.explanation: Use 'the...the' to show cause and effect with comparatives.

examples.text: You can pay either by card or in cash.
examples.explanation: Use 'either...or' to show a choice between two options.

examples.text: The harder she works, the more satisfied she feels.
examples.explanation: Use 'the...the' with different types of comparatives (short and long adjectives).

examples.text: The film was both entertaining and thought-provoking.
examples.explanation: Use 'both...and' to connect two adjectives describing one thing.

examples.text: He neither apologized nor explained.
examples.explanation: Use 'neither...nor' for two actions that didn't happen.

examples.text: The more you learn, the less you realize you know.
examples.explanation: Use 'the more...the less' to show paradoxical relationship.

title: Contrastive Linking Words
subtitle: however, whereas, on the other hand

sections.text: whereas, while: Join contrasting ideas in one sentence with a comma. 'Some like X, whereas/while others prefer Y.'
However, Nevertheless, Nonetheless: Start a new sentence to show contrast. Sentence 1. However, sentence 2. Always use comma after.
by/in contrast, on the other hand, conversely: Show direct opposition or completely opposite situations.

examples.text: Traditional methods are slow, whereas modern techniques are efficient.
examples.explanation: Use 'whereas' to contrast two things within one sentence.

examples.text: The project was expensive. However, it delivered results.
examples.explanation: Use 'However' at the start of a new sentence. Always use comma after.

examples.text: She prefers classical music, while her brother loves jazz.
examples.explanation: Use 'while' (similar to whereas) to show contrast in preferences.

examples.text: Public transport is affordable. Private cars, by contrast, are expensive.
examples.explanation: Use 'by contrast' to emphasize direct opposition.

examples.text: The task seemed impossible. Nevertheless, the team completed it.
examples.explanation: Use 'Nevertheless' to show success despite difficulty.

examples.text: Some enjoy city life, whereas others prefer rural areas.
examples.explanation: Use 'whereas' to contrast different preferences or choices.

examples.text: Theory suggests growth. The data, on the other hand, indicates decline.
examples.explanation: Use 'on the other hand' to present an opposite viewpoint.

examples.text: Critics praised the film. Nonetheless, it failed commercially.
examples.explanation: Use 'Nonetheless' (similar to nevertheless) for unexpected contrast.

examples.text: He's very sociable, whereas his sister is reserved.
examples.explanation: Use 'whereas' to contrast personality traits.

examples.text: Prices rose in cities. Conversely, they fell in rural areas.
examples.explanation: Use 'Conversely' for directly opposite situations.

sections.text: Use 'as...as' for equal comparison. 'Not as...as' shows inequality. Examples: as tall as, as expensive as.
Short adjectives (1-2 syllables): add -er (taller, faster). Long adjectives (3+ syllables): use more (more expensive). Use 'than' after.
Short adjectives: add -est (tallest, fastest). Long adjectives: use most (most expensive). Always use 'the' before superlatives.

examples.text: This phone is as expensive as that one.
examples.explanation: Use 'as...as' to show equal cost or value.

examples.text: A laptop is more convenient than a desktop.
examples.explanation: Use 'more...than' for long adjectives (3+ syllables).

examples.text: Mont Blanc is the highest mountain in Europe.
examples.explanation: Use '-est' for short adjectives in superlatives. Always use 'the'.

examples.text: She doesn't run as fast as her sister.
examples.explanation: Use 'not as...as' to show inequality.

examples.text: This solution is simpler than the previous one.
examples.explanation: Use '-er' for short adjectives (1-2 syllables).

examples.text: Shakespeare is the most famous author in English literature.
examples.explanation: Use 'the most' for long adjectives in superlatives.

examples.text: Digital books are less expensive than printed ones.
examples.explanation: Use 'less...than' to show lower degree (opposite of more).

examples.text: The exam was as difficult as last year's.
examples.explanation: Use 'as...as' to show equal difficulty.

examples.text: Summer days are longer than winter days.
examples.explanation: Long ‚Üí longer (one syllable: use -er).

examples.text: This is the most effective method.
examples.explanation: Use 'the most' with long adjectives for superlatives.

title: Superlative + Present Perfect
subtitle: the best I have ever seen

sections.text: Combine superlatives with present perfect to describe the most extreme experience in your life up to now. Very common in everyday English.
the most/-est + (noun) + subject + have/has ever + past participle. Example: the best film I have ever seen.
Use 'one of the' + superlative + plural noun to show something is among the best/worst. Example: one of the best books I have ever read.

examples.text: This is the best film I have ever seen.
examples.explanation: Use superlative + present perfect for the most extreme experience in your life.

examples.text: That's the most interesting book she has ever read.
examples.explanation: Use 'the most' + adjective + present perfect with long adjectives.

examples.text: Last summer was the worst holiday we have ever had.
examples.explanation: You can place the time reference before the superlative structure.

examples.text: Santorini is the most beautiful place I have ever visited.
examples.explanation: Common pattern: place + is + superlative + place + present perfect.

examples.text: Today was the best presentation he has ever given.
examples.explanation: Use superlative + present perfect for current events that are record-breaking.

examples.text: This project is the most difficult challenge they have ever faced.
examples.explanation: Use with abstract nouns like challenge, decision, experience.

examples.text: That was the worst food I have ever eaten.
examples.explanation: Use 'worst' (irregular superlative of bad) + present perfect.

examples.text: Her neighbor is the kindest person she has ever met.
examples.explanation: Common pattern with people: superlative + person + present perfect.

examples.text: This is one of the best concerts I have ever attended.
examples.explanation: Use 'one of the' + superlative + PLURAL noun + present perfect.

examples.text: That was one of the most inspiring speeches I have ever heard.
examples.explanation: 'One of the' shows something is among the top, not necessarily THE best.
